info.meta: How to set up a &ha; cluster with remote or guest nodes managed by &pace; and &pmrm;
Set up an HA cluster with remote nodes

revdescription.para: Updated for the initial release of &productname; &productnumber;.

sect1.title: Conceptual overview and terminology
sect1.para: A regular cluster can contain up to 32 nodes. With the &pmremote; service, &ha; clusters can be extended to include additional nodes beyond this limit.

The &pmremote; service can be operated as a physical node (called remote node) or as a virtual node (called guest node). Unlike normal cluster nodes, both remote and guest nodes are managed by the cluster as resources. As such, they are not bound to the 32 node limitation of the cluster stack. However, from the resource management point of view, they behave as regular cluster nodes.

Remote nodes do not need to have the full cluster stack installed, as they only run the &pmremote; service. The service acts as a proxy, allowing the cluster stack on the regular cluster nodes to connect to the service. Thus, the node that runs the &pmremote; service is effectively integrated into the cluster as a remote node (see ).

listitem.para: A node that runs the complete cluster stack.

textobject.phrase: Two nodes (Alice and Bob). Each node contains hardware (the physical host), the cluster stack (&pace; and &corosync;), and services (such as a web server database).

listitem.para: A regular cluster node may perform the following tasks:
Run cluster resources.
Run all command line tools, such as crm, crm_mon.
Execute fencing actions.
Count toward cluster quorum.
Serve as the cluster's designated coordinator (DC).

A service daemon that makes it possible to use a node as a &pace; node without deploying the full cluster stack. &pmremote; is the name of the systemd service. However, the name of the daemon is &pmrm_daemon; (with a trailing d after its name).

A physical machine that runs the &pmremote; daemon. A special resource (ocf:pacemaker:remote) needs to run on one of the cluster nodes to manage communication between the cluster node and the remote node (see ).

textobject.phrase: Three nodes (Alice, Bob, and Charlie). The cluster stacks for Alice and Bob include &pace; and &corosync;. The cluster stack for Charlie includes only &pace; remote.

listitem.para: A virtual machine that runs the &pmremote; daemon. A guest node is created using a resource agent such as ocf:pacemaker:VirtualDomain with the remote-node meta attribute (see ).

textobject.phrase: Two nodes (Alice and Bob). In addition to hardware, the cluster stack, and services, each node also contains virtual machines as guest nodes. The guest nodes run &pace; remote.

listitem.para: For a physical machine that contains several guest nodes, the process is as follows:
On the cluster node, virtual machines are launched by &pace;.
The cluster connects to the &pmremote; service of the virtual machines.
The virtual machines are integrated into the cluster by &pmremote;.
It is important to distinguish between several roles that a virtual machine can take in the &ha; cluster:
A virtual machine can run a full cluster stack. In this case, the virtual machine is a regular cluster node and is not itself managed by the cluster.

A virtual machine can be managed by the cluster as a resource, without the cluster being aware of the services that run inside the virtual machine. In this case, the virtual machine is opaque to the cluster.

A virtual machine can be a cluster resource and run &pmremote;, which allows the cluster to manage services inside the virtual machine. In this case, the virtual machine is a guest node and is transparent to the cluster.

sect1.para: Remote nodes and guest nodes can run cluster resources and most command line tools. However, they have the following limitations:

listitem.para: They cannot execute fencing actions.
They do not affect quorum.
They cannot serve as Designated Coordinator (DC).

sect1.title: Usage scenario
sect1.para: The procedures in this document describe the process of setting up a minimal cluster with the following characteristics:

listitem.para: Depending on the setup you choose, the cluster will have one of the following nodes:
One remote node running &pmremote; (the remote node is named &node3; in this document).
Or:
One guest node running &pmremote; (the guest node is named &node4; in this document).
&pace; to manage guest nodes and remote nodes.
Failover of resources from one node to the other if the active host breaks down (active/passive setup).

sect1.title: Use case 1: setting up a cluster with remote nodes
sect1.para: In the following example setup, a remote node &node3; is used.

sect2.title: Preparing the cluster nodes and the remote node
sect2.para: To prepare the cluster nodes and remote node, proceed as follows:

step.para: Install and set up a basic two-node cluster as described in . This leads to a two-node cluster with two physical hosts, &node1; and &node2;.

On a physical host (&node3;) that you want to use as remote node, install &sls; &productnumber; and add &productname; &productnumber; as extension. However, do not install the &ha; installation pattern, because the remote node needs only individual packages (see ).
On all cluster nodes, check /etc/hosts and add an entry for &node3;.

sect2.title: Configuring an authentication key
sect2.para: On the cluster node &node1; proceed as follows:

step.para: Create a specific authentication key for the &pmremote; service:
The key for the &pmremote; service is different from the cluster authentication key that you create in the &yast; cluster module.
Synchronize the authentication key among all cluster nodes and your future remote node with scp:
The key needs to be kept synchronized all the time.

sect2.title: Configuring the remote node
sect2.para: The following procedure configures the physical host &node3; as a remote node:

step.para: On &node3;, proceed as follows:
In the firewall settings, open the TCP port 3121 for &pmremote;.
Install the pacemaker-remote and crmsh packages:
Enable and start the &pmremote; service on &node3;:
On &node1; or &node2;, verify the host connection to the remote node by using ssh:
This SSH connection fails, but how it fails shows if the setup is working:

listitem.screen: ssh_exhange_identification: read: Connection reset by peer.
ssh: connect to host &node3; port 3121: No route to host ssh: connect to host &node3; port 3121: Connection refused
listitem.para: If you see either of those two messages, the setup does not work. Use the -v option for ssh and execute the command again to see debugging messages. This can be helpful to find connection, authentication, or configuration problems. Multiple -v options increase the verbosity.

step.para: If needed, add more remote nodes and configure them as described above.

sect2.title: Integrating the remote node into the cluster
sect2.para: To integrate the remote node into the cluster, proceed as follows:

step.para: Make sure the cluster services are already started on all the cluster nodes. If not, run the following command to start the cluster services on all nodes:
On node &node1;, create a ocf:pacemaker:remote primitive:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm configure &prompt.crm.conf;primitive &node3; ocf:pacemaker:remote \ params server=&node3; reconnect_interval=15m \ op monitor interval=30s &prompt.crm.conf;commit &prompt.crm.conf;quit

step.para: Check the status of the cluster with the command crm status. It should contain a running cluster with nodes that are all accessible:
step.screen:
&prompt.root;crm status [...] Online: [ alice bob ] RemoteOnline: [ charlie ]
Full list of resources: &node3; (ocf:pacemaker:remote): Started &node1; [...]

sect2.title: Starting resources on the remote node
sect2.para: After the remote node is integrated into the cluster, you can start resources on the remote node in the same way as on any cluster node.

warning.title: Restrictions regarding groups and constraints
warning.para: Never involve a remote node connection resource in a resource group, colocation constraint, or order constraint. This may lead to unexpected behavior on cluster transitions.

formalpara.title: Fencing remote nodes
formalpara.para: Remote nodes are fenced in the same way as cluster nodes. Configure fencing resources for use with remote nodes in the same way as with cluster nodes.

sect2.para: Remote nodes do not take part in initiating a fencing action. Only cluster nodes can execute a fencing operation against another node.

sect1.title: Use case 2: setting up a cluster with guest nodes
sect1.remark: toms 2017-07-11: Are other virtualization techniques supported, like XEN...?

gao-yan 2017-07-24: Yes. As we know libvirt also supports Xen, which means we can use the RA ocf:heartbeat:VirtualDomain to manage Xen guests as well. But of course we can either use the RA ocf:heartbeat:Xen to do that.
sect1.para: In the following example setup, KVM is used for setting up the virtual guest node (&node4;).

sect2.title: Preparing the cluster nodes and the guest node
sect2.para: To prepare the cluster nodes and guest node, proceed as follows:

step.para: Install and set up a basic two-node cluster as described in the . This leads to a two-node cluster with two physical hosts, &node1; and &node2;.
Create a KVM guest on &node1;. For details, see the &virtual; for &sls; &productnumber;.

On the KVM guest (&node4;) that you want to use as guest node, install &sls; &productnumber; and add &productname; &productnumber; as extension. However, do not install the &ha; installation pattern, because the remote node needs only individual packages (see ).
On all cluster nodes, check /etc/hosts and add an entry for &node4;.

sect2.title: Configuring an authentication key
sect2.para: On the cluster node &node1; proceed as follows:

step.para: Create a specific authentication key for the &pmremote; service:
The key for the &pmremote; service is different from the cluster authentication key that you create in the &yast; cluster module.
Synchronize the authentication key among all cluster nodes and your guest node with scp:
The key needs to be kept synchronized all the time.

sect2.title: Configuring the guest node
sect2.para: The following procedure configures &node4; as a guest node on your cluster node &node1;:

step.para: On &node4;, proceed as follows:
In the firewall settings, open the TCP port 3121 for &pmremote;.
Install the pacemaker-remote and crmsh packages:
Enable and start the &pmremote; service on &node1;:
On &node1; or &node2;, verify the host connection to the guest by running ssh:
This SSH connection fails, but how it fails shows if the setup is working:

listitem.screen: ssh_exhange_identification: read: Connection reset by peer.
ssh: connect to host &node4; port 3121: No route to host ssh: connect to host &node4; port 3121: Connection refused
listitem.para: If you see either of those two messages, the setup does not work. Use the -v option for ssh and execute the command again to see debugging messages. This can be helpful to find connection, authentication, or configuration problems. Multiple -v options increase the verbosity.

step.para: If needed, add more guest nodes and configure them as described above.
Shut down the guest node and proceed with .

sect2.title: Integrating a guest node into the cluster
sect2.para: To integrate the guest node into the cluster, proceed as follows:

step.para: Make sure the cluster services are already started on all the cluster nodes. If not, run the following command to start the cluster services on all nodes:
Dump the XML configuration of the KVM guest that you need in the next step:
step.screen: &prompt.root;virsh list --all Id Name State ----------------------------------- - &node4; shut off &prompt.root;virsh dumpxml &node4; > /etc/pacemaker/&node4;.xml

step.para: On node &node1;, create a VirtualDomain resource to launch the virtual machine. Use the dumped configuration from :
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm configure &prompt.crm.conf;primitive vm-&node4; ocf:heartbeat:VirtualDomain \ params hypervisor="qemu:///system" \ config="/etc/pacemaker/&node4;.xml" \ meta remote-node=&node4;
step.para: &pace; automatically monitors &pmrm; connections for failure, so it is not necessary to create a recurring monitor on the VirtualDomain resource.

tip.title: Enabling live migration
tip.para: To enable live migration of the resource, set the meta attribute allow-migrate to true. The default is false.

step.para: Check the status of the cluster with the command crm status. It should contain a running cluster with nodes that are all accessible.

sect2.title: Testing the setup
sect2.para: To demonstrate how resources are executed, use a dummy resource. It serves for testing purposes only.

step.para: Create a dummy resource:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm configure primitive fake1 ocf:pacemaker:Dummy \ op monitor timeout=20s interval=10s

step.para: Check the cluster status with the crm status command. You should see something like the following:
step.screen:
&prompt.root;crm status [...] Online: [ &node1; &node2; ] GuestOnline: [ &node4;@&node1; ]
Full list of resources: vm-doro (ocf:heartbeat:VirtualDomain): Started &node1; fake1 (ocf:pacemaker:Dummy): Started &node2;

step.para: To move the Dummy primitive to the guest node (&node4;), use the following command:
The status changes to this:
step.screen:
&prompt.root;crm status [...] Online: [ &node1; &node2; ] GuestOnline: [ &node4;@&node1; ]
Full list of resources: vm-doro (ocf:heartbeat:VirtualDomain): Started &node1; fake1 (ocf:pacemaker:Dummy): Started &node4;

step.para: To test whether fencing works, kill the pacemaker-remoted daemon on &node4;:
After a few seconds, check the status of the cluster again. It should look like this:
step.screen:
&prompt.root;crm status [...] Online: [ &node1; &node2; ]
Full list of resources: vm-&node4; (ocf::heartbeat:VirtualDomain): Started &node1; fake1 (ocf:pacemaker:Dummy): Stopped
Failed Actions: * &node4;_monitor_30000 on alice 'unknown error' (1): call=8, status=Error, exitreason='none', last-rc-change='Tue Jul 18 13:11:51 2017', queued=0ms, exec=0ms
